metadata.title: Convert Calories to Joules – Energy Converter
metadata.description: Convert energy from Calories (cal) to Joules (J), essential for chemistry and scientific calculations.

introduction: This converter transforms calories to joules, converting legacy nutrition units to SI standard.
Chemistry and physics exclusively use joules while nutrition still references calories.
This converter uses the relationship where 1 calorie equals exactly 4.184 joules.
methodology: 1 cal = 4.184 J exactly. To convert calories to joules, multiply by 4.184.
SI standardization replaced calories with joules in all scientific work.
Understanding calorie-to-joule conversion bridges chemistry and nutrition contexts.
This converter provides precise energy conversion for scientific calculations.
examples: Example 2 – Nutrition quantity: 1,000 cal (food Cal) = 4,184 J = 4.184 kJ.
Example 3 – Daily intake: 2,000 food calories = 8,368 kJ = 8.368 MJ.

faqs.question: Is 1 calorie really 4.184 joules?
faqs.answer: Yes, by definition. 1 calorie = energy to raise 1g water by 1°C. Equals 4.184 J exactly.

faqs.question: Why multiply by 4.184 specifically?
faqs.answer: Heat capacity of water = 4.184 J/g°C. This defines the calorie.

faqs.question: How much is 100 calories in joules?
Do modern food labels use joules?
faqs.answer: Many countries now require both: calories (kcal) and joules (kJ). Gradually shifting to kJ.

faqs.question: Why didn't the US adopt joules for food?
faqs.answer: Historical resistance. FDA still permits calorie labels. Other countries adopted kJ officially.

faqs.question: Can I memorize the conversion?
faqs.answer: Approximate: 1 cal ≈ 4 J. 1 food Cal ≈ 4,200 J. Exact: multiply by 4.184.

faqs.question: How is water calorie defined differently?
faqs.answer: Different types: gram calorie (small cal) vs kilogram calorie (kcal). Food uses kilogram version.

faqs.question: What's the relationship with nutrition science?
faqs.answer: Nutrition uses kcal (kilocalories). Chemistry uses joules. Conversion needed between fields.
